facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 239 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal -No. 239 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 12, 1950, of the Patna High Court

facts.text: Appeal from Patna High Court judgment dated December 12, 1950 in Appeal from Original Decree No. 188 of 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 12, 1950, of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 188 of 1945 arising out of the judgment and decree dated December 18, 1945,

facts.text: Original suit Title Suit No. 4 of 1945 decided by Additional Subordinate Judge IV Class, Gaya on December 18, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: of the Court of the Additional Subordinate Judge, IV Class, Gaya, in Title Suit No. 4 of 1945.

facts.text: Deokinand executed document dated August 20, 1923 in favour of Mahant Tokhnarain Puri hypothecating eight annas milkiat share in mauza Lodipur, Mahimabigha, Tauze No. 4246 for Rs. 31,701 debt.

anchor.surface_text: Deokinand, the common ancestor of plaintiff-respondents 1 to 4 and proforma respondents 6 to 12, executed a document dated August 20, 1923, in favour of Mahant Tokhnarain Puri of Nadra, the predecessor-ininterest of defendant 1, hypothecating eight annas milkiat share in mauza Lodipur, Mahimabigha, Tauze No. 4246 for the purpose of discharging a debt of Rs. 31,701 payable by him to the Mahanth.

facts.text: Respondents claim the 1923 document is a usufructuary mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: There are conflicting versions in regard to the nature of this transaction-respondents claim it to be a usufructuary mortgage, while the appellant asserts it to be a lease

facts.text: Appellant claims the 1923 document is a lease.

anchor.surface_text: while the appellant asserts it to be a lease The plaintiff-respondents instituted Title Suit No. 4 of 1945 in the Court of the Additional Subordinate Judge 1V, Gaya,

facts.text: Plaintiff-respondents instituted Title Suit No. 4 of 1945 for redemption, accounts, and surplus profits.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff-respondents instituted Title Suit No. 4 of 1945 in the Court of the Additional Subordinate Judge 1V, Gaya, for redemption of the said document on the basis that it was a usufructuary mortgage, for rendition of accounts and for the recovery of surplus profits due to them.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held document is usufructuary mortgage, s.77 T.P. Act applies, no accounts liability; conditional decree for possession on deposit of Rs. 26,839-7-0.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge held that the document created a usufructuary mortgage and not a lease and that s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act applied to the document exonerating the appellant from any liability to render accounts. In the result, the learned Subordinate Judge gave a conditional decree in favour of respondents 1 to 4 for possession on their depositing in Court a sum of Rs. 26,839-7-0 within six months from the date of the decree.

facts.text: Patna High Court agreed document is usufructuary mortgage but held s.77 T.P. Act not applicable; passed preliminary decree for redemption, sale on default, and accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the learned Subordinate Judge that the document was a usufructuary mortgage but differed from him on the question of applicability of s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act. The High Court set aside the decree of the learned Subordinate Judge and passed instead a preliminary decree for redemption and sale on default of payment the decree also directed the rendition of accounts between the parties in the light of the directions given in the judgment.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) Constitution against Patna High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate under Art. 133 1 a of the Constitution of India is directed against the judgment and decree of the High Court of Judicature at Patna setting aside those of the Subordinate Judge, Gaya, in a suit for redemption of an usufructuary mortgage.

facts.text: Pre-existing thika lease dated April 21, 1922 in favour of Munshi Dodraj Lal alias Munshi Jatadhari Lal for 9 years, Rs. 2,205 peshgi, rent Rs. 2,205.

anchor.surface_text: It was also stated in the document that in respect of the said property there was a pre-existing thika lease dated April 21, 1922, in favour of Munshi Dodraj Lal alias Munshi Jatadhari Lal, for a period of 9 years and that under the said lease, Rs. 2,205 was taken by the executant as peshgi money without interest and the rent was fixed at a sum of Rs. 2,205.

facts.text: 1923 document term: 15 years from 1331 Fasli to 1345 Fasli.

anchor.surface_text: for a term of 15 years, commencing from 1331 Fasli to 1345 Fasli and have put him in possession and occupation of the ijara property as my representative.

facts.text: Peshgi money Rs. 31,701: Rs. 29,496 at 1/2% per month interest, Rs. 2,205 without interest; annual rental Rs. 2,205.

anchor.surface_text: have voluntarily let out in ijara with possession the whole and entire 8 annas i. e., half of Mauza Lodipur Mahima Bighafor a peshgi money of Rs. 31,701that Rs. 29,496, the peshgi money bearing interest at 1/2 per cent. per month and Rs. 2,205, tile peshgi money without interest, at an annual rental of Rs. 2,205 including revenue and cesses,

facts.text: During thikadari subsistence, ijaradar to realize rent Rs. 2,205, set off Rs. 1,769-12-0 for interest, pay Rs. 435-4-0 to executant.

anchor.surface_text: so long as the thika of Munshi Dodraj Lal alias Jatadhari Lal is intact and in force, he should realize the rent from the above-named thikadars and their heirs and representatives in accordance with the stipulations made in the thika patta and kabuliat as representative of me, the executant, and bring it into his possession and use, that is to say, on his own authority he should set off Rs. 1,769-12-0 on account of the interest on the peshgi money bearing interest mentioned in this deed, year after year, and pay the remaining sum of Rs. 435-4-0,

facts.text: After thikadari expiry (1338 Fasli), ijaradar takes sir possession, appropriates produce, pays Rs. 435-4-0 rent.

anchor.surface_text: The ijaradar of this ijara deed or his heirs and representatives on his own authority shall be competent to bring the thika property into his sir possession as ijara property as a representative of me, the executant, ... realise the nakdi and jinsi income of the ijara property from the tenants and appropriate the produce of both the shares thereof. 1, the executant, and my heirs and representatives neither have nor shall have any right, claim and. demand in respect of tile produce or the income of the ijara property so long as the ijara deed is intact except getting Rs. 435-4-0,

facts.text: Executant to repay Rs. 31,701 peshgi on expiry Jeth 1345 Fasli, else deed continues.

anchor.surface_text: The term of this ijara deed with possession shall terminate in the month of Jeth, 1345 Fasli, when 1, the executant, or my heirs and representatives shall repay Rs. 31,701 being the peshgi money with and without interest mentioned in this deed in cash and in one lump sum to the said ijaradar or his heirs and representatives, ... If I do not repay the peshgi money with and without interest on the expiry of the term of this ijara deed with possession, then, till the repayment of the whole and entire peshgi money with and without interest, this ijara deed with possession shall precisely with all the stipulations remain in force and intact.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds document is mortgage, not lease.

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, no scope for the argument in this case that the document is a lease and not a mortgage. We hold, agreeing with the High Court, that the document is a mortgage and not a lease.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds s.77 T.P. Act applies, mortgagee not liable to render accounts.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act applies to the document and therefore the mortgagee is not liable to render any account to the mortgagor.

facts.text: Even if anomalous mortgage, contract terms govern, no accounts liability.

anchor.surface_text: Whether s. 77 applies or not, under the express terms of the contract, the appellant is not liable to render accounts for the excess receipts.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court decree, restores Subordinate Judge decree.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the decree of the High Court is set aside and that of the Subordinate Judge is restored.

facts.text: Thikadari interest expires in 1338 Fasli.

anchor.surface_text: after the expiry of the thikadari interest in 1338 Fasli,

facts.text: Previous mortgage bonds discharged by endorsement, amount set off against peshgi.

anchor.surface_text: The peshgi money amounting to Rs. 31,701 with and without interest as mentioned in this ijara deed has been realized from the ijaradar in this manner that I allowed Rs. 28,246, the amount of loan principal with simple and compound interest as per account given below after remission of the interest due to the ijaradar under all the three mortgage bonds to be set off against the peshgi money by getting a note made to that effect on the back of the said mortgage bonds

facts.text: Executant owed large sums to Mahanth under mortgage bonds and otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: The executant was indebted to the other party in a large amount under mortgage bonds and otherwise.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded document is lease, not mortgage; if mortgage, anomalous, no statutory accounts; if usufructuary, s.77 applies.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded, inter alia, that the suit for redemption was not maintainable as the document was not a mortgage but lease, that on the assumption that it was a mortgage it would only be an anomalous mortgage in respect whereof there was no statutory liability to render accounts to the plaintiff, that even if it was a usufructuary mortgage, it was governed by the provisions of s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act taking the mortgage out of the purview of s. 76 d and g of the said Act.

facts.text: Mahant Tokhnarain Puri is predecessor-in-interest of defendant 1 (appellant).

anchor.surface_text: in favour of Mahant Tokhnarain Puri of Nadra, the predecessor-ininterest of defendant 1,

This appeal by certificate tinder Art. 133  1   a  of the Constitution of India is directed against the judgment and decree of the High Court of Judicature at Patna setting aside those of the Subordinate Judge, Gaya, in a suit for redemption of an usufructuary mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The only guiding rule that can be extracted from the cases on the subject is that the intention of the parties must be looked into and that once you get a debt with security of land for its redemption, then the arrangement is a mortgage by whatever name it is called  See Ghosh on Mortgages, V Edn., Vol. 1, p. 102 . Let us now examine the terms of the document Exhibit A  3  to ascertain the intention of the parties.

issues.text: whether the transaction is a lease as contended by the contesting respondents

anchor.surface_text: The point to be first decided is whether the transaction is a lease as contended by the contesting respondents. The only guiding rule that can be extracted from the cases on the subject is that the intention of the parties must be looked into and that once you get a debt with security of land for its redemption, then the arrangement is a mortgage by whatever name it is called

issues.text: whether s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act applies to the document exonerating the mortgagee from liability to render accounts

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the learned Subordinate Judge that the document was a usufructuary mortgage but differed from him on the question of applicability of s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act. The High Court set aside the decree of the learned Subordinate Judge and passed instead a preliminary decree for redemption and sale on default of payment the decree also directed the rendition of accounts between the parties in the light of the directions given in the judgment.

issues.text: whether the document created a usufructuary mortgage or only an anomalous mortgage

anchor.surface_text: Even so, it was contended by the learned Counsel for the appellant that the document did not create an usufructuary mortgage but only an anomalous mortgage. This contention was raised as a foundation to the argument that if the document was an anomalous mortgage, the rights and liabilities of the parties would be governed by the terms of the contract between them and not by the provisions of s. 76 of the Transfer of Property Act.

issues.text: whether under the terms of the contract in case of anomalous mortgage, the mortgagee is liable to render accounts

anchor.surface_text: Whether s. 77 applies or not, under the express terms of the contract, the appellant is not liable to render accounts for the excess receipts.

issues.text: whether the mortgagee was authorized to take the receipts in lieu of interest within the meaning of s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act

anchor.surface_text: If it was a usufructuary mortgage, it is contended by the appellant that he was not liable to render accounts to the mortgagor, as, under the mortgage deed, he was authorized to take the receipts in lieu of interest within the meaning of s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act. anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, no scope for the argument in this case that the document is a lease and not a mortgage. We hold, agreeing with the High Court, that the document is a mortgage and not a lease.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document creates debt relationship with land as security for repayment; explicit hypothecation and intention override lease nomenclature; applies standard test from precedents.

holdings.text: We hold that s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act applies to the document and therefore the mortgagee is not liable to render any account to the mortgagor.
